title: Queensland premier ends 'cannoli diplomacy' with PM over hospital funding snub
text:
David Crisafulli once said of Prime Minister Anthony Albanese that there's nothing that the pair can't solve over a bit of common sense and an Italian meal.

But seems Crisafulli has found the dealbreaker in their so-called "cannoli diplomacy".

The Queensland﻿ premier is expected today to formally reject the federal government's hospital funding proposal and has blasted the PM for shortchanging the state.

Queensland Premier David Crisafulli is expected to reject the federal government's hospital funding plan. (Jamila Filippone)

The proposal would see Australian states and territories share in about 35 per cent of the Commonwealth's share of hospital funding – a major shortfall of the 42.5 per cent originally promised.

It was originally proposed that the federal share of public hospital funding will rise from 40.3 per cent to 42.5 per cent by 2030.

The premier said this new figure is not something he is willing to accept for Queensland.﻿

"We will not allow the Commonwealth to short-change Queensland's health system," Crisafulli said.

"Cannoli diplomacy is off the menu until a fair health deal is back on the table."

The premier said his longstanding "cannoli diplomacy" with the PM has come to an end. (Dominic Lorrimer)

Crisafulli has also accused the government of leaving hundreds of Queenslanders with mild disabilities stranded in the state's hospital system.

Part of the hospital deal would see states co-fund new supports which are aimed at moving people with mild autism off the NDIS.

Crisafulli said earlier he expects other state leaders to follow suit.﻿

title: Aussies like Cassie have resorted to selling their clothes to make ends meet
text:
Exclusive: Melbourne woman Cassie Walker started selling her old clothes online as a way to "make quick cash when times are tough".

New research shows she's not the only one.﻿

It's estimated that millions of Australians ﻿have recently picked up a side hustle to cope with financial pressure in the cost-of-living crisis.

Cassie Walker started selling her old clothes as a way to "make quick cash when times are tough". (Supplied)

One in four Aussies currently have a side hustle according to an Omnisend survey , and more than three-quarters of them started out of financial need – not for "fun money".

Almost 50 per cent started within the last 12 months.

Most spend up to 10 hours on their side hustle per week.﻿

But only one in five make more than $1000 per month (around $250 per week).

It doesn't sound like much but Aussies are collectively earning an extra $14.3 billion per month from side hustles, based on the Omnisend data.

The survey also revealed that about 45 per cent of Aussies with side hustles have turned to online sales, using resale platforms like eBay and Facebook Marketplace to make quick cash off their old clothes and household items.﻿

Walker has been freelancing in TV and media production for the past three years and relies on the extra cash from her side hustle to get by between contracts.

"I first started selling on [fashion marketplace] Depop five years ago," she told 9news.com.au.

"I was working full-time but my hours were cut to one day per week [so] it was a financial decision first."

Some of the pieces she sells are from her own wardrobe, others she picks up cheap at op shops and resells at a higher value.

Often this is because she's upcycled the piece, turning a $2 buy into a $20 sale with a few small repairs.﻿

READ MORE: How to maximise public holidays and make the most of your annual leave in 2025

Highest-paying jobs in Australia that don't need a degree View Gallery

Walker also sells items on her social media pages from time to time, using Facebook and Instagram stories to advertise to her friends and followers.﻿

Now she makes an average of $100 per week from the side hustle, sometimes more.

Last week, she pocketed $160 – enough to cover common monthly expenses like a phone bill or insurance fees for the average Aussie.

"It's also helpful for those unexpected bills or more expensive weeks," she said.

"I can easily sell something and have that cashflow."

Walker spends about a day a month organising her side hustle. (Supplied)

The best part about Walker's side hustle?

She doesn't have to invest loads of time into it.

"I put aside one day per month on photos, uploading, managing existing listings, et cetera," Walker said.

"I do maintenance a few times a week, like sending offers to those liking my items, sending discount offers, changing photo orders and prices."

The majority of Aussies with side hustles are the same.

About 35 per cent spend less than five hours on their side hustle per week.

More than 40 per cent spend just five to 10 hours on it per week.

For most, including Walker, it allows them to make enough to bridge the gap between their main source of income and the rising cost of living.

﻿Especially in an age of job insecurity and growing adoption of AI in the workplace.

"As a woman approaching 40 I'm finding it very hard to find permanent work," Walker confessed.

"I know I'm not alone in this, but while I'm juggling [freelance work] this is a great side hustle."

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

title: Punters brave Flemington as wild weather lashes Melbourne
text:
Wild weather has lashed Melbourne on the final day of the Melbourne Cup carnival.

Raincoats and umbrellas were the accessory of the day for racegoers who braved the spring soaking.﻿

The 65,000-strong crowd at Flemington were hit with sideways rain, strong winds and a downpour for Stakes Day.

READ MORE: Labor legend Graham Richardson dies at 76 ﻿

Raincoats and umbrellas were the accessory of the day for racegoers who braved the spring soaking.﻿ (9News)

The temperature dropped to 10 degrees ﻿with a 'feels like' temperature just shy of six degrees across the day.

It was a dramatic contrast to yesterday's weather, which was a maximum of 28 degrees with a "feels like" temperature of about 25 degrees.

The 65,000-strong crowd at Flemington were hit with sideways rain, strong winds and a downpour for Stakes Day. (9News)

Young racegoers are seen in the rain during Champions Day at Flemington Racecourse. (Getty)

﻿Today's showers are expected to continue in the Victorian capital until Tuesday but temperatures will rise slightly.

The mercury will climb to 15 degrees for Sunday, warm up to 20 degrees on Monday before the forecast dips back to 15 degrees on Tuesday.

READ MORE: Salad pulled from shelves due to salmonella fears after 44 people become ill

12:25 AEDT 12:30 AEDT 12:35 AEDT 12:40 AEDT 12:45 AEDT 12:50 AEDT 12:55 AEDT

Meanwhile the heat is peaking in eastern parts of NSW, with temperatures expected to reach at 36 degrees in Penrith and 33 degrees in Sydney.

Nowra on the state's south coast and Dubbo in the central west could reach a ﻿top of 33 degrees.﻿

Weatherzone predicts many locations lose at least 10 degrees for their Sunday maximums .﻿

Large hail stones and damaging winds could affect parts of these communities this afternoon.﻿

title: 21-year-old business owner reveals mistake jobseekers keep making
text:
Exclusive: In a new nine.com.au series starting today we'll be talking to some of Australia's smartest and sharpest ﻿entrepreneurs, founders and CEOs to find out what makes them tick - and what advice they'd have for anyone starting out.

Sophia Begg (known online as @sophadophaa) is one of Australia's most recognisable young influencers ﻿with more than 2 million combined social media followers.

She's also co-founder of All For Mimi, the wildly successful fashion brand she launched in 2023 that shot to fame for its viral sell-out tank tops.

Now a successful internet personality and business owner, she's juggling two lucrative careers ﻿at just 21 years old.

﻿ These are her secrets to success.

Sophia Begg is one of Australia's most recognisable young influencers and co-founder of fashion brand All For Mimi. (Supplied)

How do you start the day to set yourself up for success?

I love to start the day with a morning walk with my partner before making my Tropeaka matcha to enjoy a quiet moment before the chaos!

What are three daily habits you always stick to?

Morning matcha, daily gratitude, and 'no-phone' time before bed.

Lots of Aussies are looking for a career change — what small action can help them get ahead of other candidates?

What stands out to me is when applicants take the time to attend to the finer details.

You'd be surprised at how many applications don't have a cover letter or have spelling errors!

Begg revealed a surprising number of people who apply to work with her don't include a cover letter. (Supplied)

What financial myth do you wish you never bought into?

In my first ever car, when I was 18, I believed that if I put my windows down the car would go slower and therefore use more petrol.

So even in summer, in 30 degree heat, I would keep my windows up and never use the aircon to save money.

What do you wish you could tell your 20-year-old self?

Last year [Begg turned 20 in 2024] was a wild one as it was the first year of my brand All For Mimi.

I would tell my 20-year-old self to speak kindly to herself, take each "mistake" as a learning curve, and keep moving forward.

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

title: 'Hellscape' fire in Tongariro National Park, New Zealand
text:
A business owner says Tongariro National Park, on New Zealand's North Island, resembles a hellscape as a massive forest fire continues to burn out of control.

Fire and Emergency New Zealand (FENZ) said the blaze has swelled in size and is now estimated to be covering about 1000ha.

Dozens of hikers have been evacuated from the park, and the public is asked to stay away from the area.

Loading Instagram content

Skotel Alpine Resort owner Sam Clarkson said the resort had a grandstand view of the fire on Saturday night.

"It was like a hellscape — welcome to Mordor — it really was," he said.

"Last night, there was quite a brisk westerly wind, which pushed the fire both east and northwards and the wall of flame was enormous … I would estimate some of those flames are 30 metres high.

"It was hard to see across the flames to the far side, but any time we did, it was just this wall of orange that was at least 4 kilometres long. Everything the fire service was valiantly trying to throw at it was achieving nothing."

He said, fortunately, the fire was heading away from his resort, progressing up the Mangatepopo Road towards the Tongariro Crossing.

Spring bushfire outlook released Parts of Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria will see increased fire risk this spring, as emergency services unveil their outlook for the season.

The wind had since dropped along with a blanket of fog on Sunday morning, but rain was not forecast until Monday, Mr Clarkson said.

"I watched, literally weeping as the fire went closer and closer and closer to the hill, Pukeonake, which is a sensitive sub-alpine environment where the little communities of plant life all huddle together and live out their lives, and it just got toasted," he said.

"It's just an ecological disaster. There is no risk to people or structures, unless the wind really got up."

Despite six weeks of rain, the fire has proven to be insatiable, he added.

"The park was utterly saturated and then it fined up about a week ago, and I think we'd only had seven or eight days of fine weather in a row after a good six weeks of solid rain, so you would not think it's that tinder dry," Mr Clarkson said.

"But the predominant species in the park, at least on the flats, is tea tree, and tea tree is the most flammable native plant there is — once it's off, it's away."

The community had rallied together in the face of the evacuation and closure of Tongariro National Park, he said.

On Saturday, 43 hikers and a warden from Mangatepopo Hut were airlifted out in response to the fire, according to the Department of Conservation (DOC).

"In fact, we ended up putting up those people and feeding them … we were part of the effort to look after everybody," Mr Clarkson said.

On Sunday morning, a further nine hikers were evacuated from the national park, having left Waihohonu Hut, a DOC spokesperson said.

DOC said it expects there will be "significant biodiversity impacts", given the size of the fire.

'Pretty chill about it'

A local who runs a food truck in Waimarino, a township near Tongariro National Park, said locals were hopeful the fire would not be fanned by winds that had picked up slightly on Sunday.

Johnny Ryburn said he was down swimming at the Whakapapa River on Saturday when the blaze began.

"It pretty much kicked off while I was out there," he said. "It was pretty small when it started, and from what I know it started around the the road that takes you towards the Tongariro Crossing. From there it just got massive and went up the road and stuck towards the side of Tongariro."

Despite this, locals were not too worried, Mr Ryburn said.

"Everybody's still pretty chill about it, you know? I think because it seems to be staying a lot closer to Tongariro and [Mount] Ngauruhoe people aren't super concerned," he said.

A number of helicopters with monsoon buckets and planes are fighting the blaze in Tongariro National Park. (RNZ: Hamish Cardwell)

Six fire trucks, five tankers, six helicopters and two planes

Firefighters from Taranaki and Manawatū-Whanganui were briefed on Sunday morning before beginning work on the second day of operations.

Assistant Commander Nick West said the fire service will have six fire trucks and five tankers on the fireground, supported by six helicopters and two aeroplanes.

There are no reports of structures being damaged or destroyed and no residents were evacuated overnight.

Mr West said it could take a full day of operations to bring the fire under control.

An RNZ reporter on the scene said the southern line of the fire stretched from State Highway 47 a number of kilometres east into the scrub and young pine, but it was not clear whether the fire had reached the Tongariro crossing track itself.

The were huge flames in a couple of places in the line, and helicopters appeared to be concentrating on those areas.

The cause of the fire has not been established and a specialist wildfire investigator will be working on Sunday.

Weather outlook raises bushfire risk An atmospheric "tug of war" for control of Australia's weather is taking place this spring, and it is a forecasting nightmare.

Residents in the area are being urged to stay alert to the fire, and keep doors and windows shut to minimise exposure to the smoke. Anyone who feels unsafe, or is vulnerable to smoke is encouraged to self-evacuate and stay with family or friends.

FENZ advises those to the north of the fire should go towards Turangi and those to the south of the fire should go towards National Park.

State Highway 47 Waimarino to Tongariro remains closed between the intersections with State Highway 48 and State Highway 46 with no detours available.

The Department of Conservation has closed the Tongariro Crossing and associated areas.

A no-fly zone is in place covering the airspace over the fireground and surrounding area, so that firefighting aircraft are not endangered by other aircraft or drones.

Radio New Zealand

title: Blanket ban on controversial mining practice one step closer
text:
A controversial mining technique — hydraulic fracturing, or fracking — is one step closer to ending in Western Australia, after WA Labor party members voted for a blanket ban.

Fracking involves drilling and pumping fluid into the ground to create fractures, allowing oil and gas to flow to the surface.

Currently, the fracking ban applies to 98 per cent of WA. The technique is permitted in parts of the Kimberley and Mid West regions under strict regulations and approval processes.

Loading...

However Labor party members voted to extend the ban to all parts of WA at the party's state conference on Saturday, the first since WA Labor started its third term in government.

The move is a departure from the WA Government's current policy, implemented under former premier Mark McGowan, to allow fracking in two per cent of the state.

WA Labor under pressure over fracking ban WA Labor called on to ban fracking to 100 per cent of the state.

In order for the total ban to be implemented, legislation would need to be passed by the WA parliament.

When asked about the issue on Saturday morning, Premier Roger Cook said it was important to balance environmental needs with energy and economic considerations.

"We want to make sure that we protect the environment, and we want to make sure that Western Australians have access to gas," Mr Cook said.

"Ninety eight per cent of Western Australia is currently not eligible for fracking … so in Western Australia we already have incredibly stringent arrangements in relation to that sort of resource."

Roger Cook says WA has placed strict conditions on fracking. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

Environment groups back blanket ban

Environmental group Environs Kimberley executive director Martin Pritchard threatened to campaign against a fourth Labor term in government if it didn't rule out fracking.

"We're going to be working really hard to make sure that people understand what the threat is to the Kimberley, and we believe that's going to be a major problem for Labor," Mr Pritchard said.

"Fracking is banned in the South West, Perth and Peel, and we want it extended to ban fracking in the Kimberley."

Martin Pritchard has called for a total fracking ban in the Kimberley. (ABC Kimberley: Dunja Karagic )

Mangala Martu Traditional Owner Nuriah Jadai said fracking had the potential to contaminate natural waterways.

"We just want to keep it safe, we want to keep it clean, we want to keep it fresh for us, and also for the next generation," Ms Jadai said.

Nuriah Jadai is concerned about the environmental impact of fracking in the Kimberley. (ABC News)

The state's Environmental Protection Authority is assessing a proposal by US-based oil and gas company Black Mountain Energy to develop a fracking project in the West Kimberley.

The company is proposing to develop "one of the world's last large scale onshore unconventional undeveloped gas projects".

"Black Mountain Energy is committed to protecting the environment to achieve long-term sustainable operations," the company's environment policy statement said.

title: Beer-fuelled strategy the key to success in 100-mile race
text:
More than 700 athletes from 27 nations descended on the Grampians/Gariwerd National Park in western Victoria this week, chasing glory in Australia's first internationally recognised ultra-distance trail event.

Among the runners in the 100-mile race was Nepal's Sangé Sherpa, whose beer-fuelled strategy and mountain-hardened endurance made him a crowd favourite, even if he did not take the win when he crossed the line on Saturday.

"Sometimes if there's a beer [offered en route], I just drink it," he said.

"Usually after the race we enjoy [a beer] a lot, so why not during the race?

"It can change your mind and help you overcome the pain and struggle."

Sangé Sherpa has competed in ultramarathon races across the globe. (ABC News: Peter Quattrocelli)

The 44-year-old works as a porter on Kangchenjunga in Nepal's eastern region, and he said his transition into trail running was a natural progression from his life at home.

"I was born in a very remote village," he said.

" No cars, no transportation — everything you do is on your feet. Since childhood I've been in nature. "

The 100-mile event took most competitors more than 24 hours to complete. (Supplied: GPT 100)

In 2025, Sherpa has already completed ultra-distance races in Hong Kong, France, Spain, Switzerland, Thailand and Indonesia.

After taking line honours in last year's Grampians race, he faced stiff competition from a field of international runners this year, drawn by the event's official recognition as part of the World Trail Majors circuit.

Sherpa finished the 100-mile course in just over 26 hours, finishing sixth in the men's category.

American athlete Caleb Olsen, currently ranked as the second-best 100-miler in the world, claimed victory in a course record time of just over 21 hours.

Hong Kong competitor Man Yee Cheung won the women's 100-mile race in just under 28 hours.

Grampians joins global trail running elite

The Grampians race is the only leg of the tour in Oceania, joining events held in iconic locations like Mt Fuji in Japan and the Pyrenees in France.

"What a privilege it is for the Grampians to play host to the Australian leg, representing this region on a global stage," event director Colin Taylor said.

More than 700 runners from 27 nations competed this year across two events — a 50-kilometre race and a 100-mile race.

"For many of them, it was their very first time in Australia and their first time in the Grampians," Mr Taylor said.

Sangé Sherpa racing on the Grampians Peak Trail in 2024. (Supplied: GPT 100)

He said the race followed the entire Grampians Peak Trail across the mountain range, from Mount Zero in the north to Dunkeld in the south.

"There are lots of 100-mile races throughout the world, but what's unique about this one is that it's single-track," he said.

"What that means is incredibly technical terrain underfoot — your body and mind are constantly having to work."

More than 700 athletes took part in this year's events. (Supplied: Kate Proctor)

The Victorian and federal governments invested a combined $34 million into the national park, with the Grampians Peak Trail opening in 2021.

While trail running might still be considered niche in some circles, the sport has a dedicated following, and the Grampians event has grown sevenfold since its inception in 2023.

The state government believes the event could become a major tourism drawcard for western Victoria.

Tourism Minister Steve Dimopoulos compared it to the Cadel Evans Great Ocean Road Race, citing the positive impact it could have on local accommodation and hospitality businesses.

"It will start gaining gravitas, and we can help it become even more prominent — this kind of sport lends itself so well to tourism," Mr Dimopoulos said.

title: Former nurse turns 'absolute passion' for lavender into 35-year career
text:
Annemarie Manders has hitchhiked across Europe, nursed patients for hours on end, raised two sons and grieved for her late husband, but one of her greatest challenges has involved a small purple flower.

"I stumbled into growing lavender," she said.

"All I knew was it was a purple flower with a lovely fragrance, so I started out very green."

Annemarie Manders grows two varieties of lavender. (ABC Rural: Faith Tabalujan)

Ms Manders has been growing lavender in Victoria's picturesque Yarra Valley for 35 years, but she never dreamed of becoming a farmer.

"I trained and worked as an operating theatre nurse, so I knew nothing about agriculture," she said.

"But my husband and I bought this old cherry orchard block and wanted to make use of the land."

Today the farm is home to more than 12,000 plants of the Lavandula intermedia and Lavandula angustifolia classifications.

Ms Manders she and her husband faced a steep learning curve.

"We had no equipment and no buildings — we didn't even have a tractor," she said.

"But I'm quite impetuous, so I just jumped in the deep end and made plenty of mistakes along the way."

Annemarie Manders has transformed an old cherry orchard into a lavender agritourism business. (ABC Rural: Faith Tabalujan)

Today the farm attracts lavender lovers from around Australia and beyond.

"We've turned it into an agritourism destination," Ms Manders said.

"So people flock here from November to January when the lavender is in full bloom and we also teach them how it is grown and harvested."

A 'neat, tidy' crop

Ms Manders said she was immediately drawn to lavender.

"I'm a very organised person, which was always important when arranging instruments on the operating table," she said.

"So I just love how lavender grows in such neat, tidy rows."

But Ms Manders said it was also a versatile crop.

"We grow two kinds of lavender — one to put into food products such as teas, ice creams, scones, and cakes," she said.

"The other is used in craft products or sold as bunches to wholesale flower markets as far as Sydney and Brisbane."

Lavender can be added to various food, including scones. (ABC Rural: Faith Tabalujan)

Ms Manders said timing was crucial when it came to harvesting.

"We pick the edible lavender at the end of November and then the non-edible lavender about a month later," she said.

Lavender is best picked in the morning, according to Ms Manders.

"We start picking very early, at around 5:30am or 6am, because that's when the flowers are crisp and the lavender fragrance is at its strongest," she said.

"We then hang all the bunches upside down in the drying shed, where they dry for about two weeks."

Victoria's lavender plants are in full bloom from late spring. (ABC Rural: Faith Tabalujan)

Once the lavender is dried, it is sifted to remove sticks and leaves and poured into a large container.

Ms Manders said her approach was positively old-fashioned.

"You could automate this process, but I'd prefer it to be hands-on so people can see, touch, and smell all the stripped lavender," she said.

"And it's a gorgeous experience."

An 'absolute passion'

For Ms Manders, growing lavender is a labour of love.

"From the start I knew I wouldn't make much money," she said.

"But it's an absolute passion of mine and I was determined that the farm would not fail."

Annemarie Manders says she hopes to keep growing lavender for years to come. (ABC Rural: Faith Tabalujan)

Ms Manders said she had no intention of retiring.

"I've been doing this for 35 years and don't think I'll stop anytime soon," she said.

"But when I do, I'll be pushing up another lavender bush I think!"

title: 'Dodging them everywhere': Warning to SA drivers over kangaroo risk increase
text:
Kangaroo collisions are on the rise across South Australia and regional drivers are urged to take extra care on country roads.

RAA, the state's peak motoring body, has observed a sharp increase in insurance claims from kangaroo collisions over the past year.

In the South East, casual school bus driver Graeme White says mobs of kangaroos are regularly lining the roads during his morning run into Narracorte.

Graeme White says kangaroo activity has increased all around the South East and into western Victoria. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

Mr White, who has done the route on-and-off for the past eight years and has been driving on these rural roads for more than 50 years, said he and other bus drivers were seeing more kangaroos than they ever had.

"You're dodging them everywhere now," he said.

"When you head out of town, the numbers of kangaroos that are feeding in the mornings out in the paddock have increased ... you could see 15 to 40 kangaroos at one time."

This increased activity has caused him concern about road safety in the region.

While a kangaroo would not likely cause an injury to passengers when hit by a bus, the damage it could do is still significant.

A mob of kangaroos near the road on the outskirts of Naracoorte. (Supplied: Graeme White)

But the safety risk is much higher for smaller vehicles.

Two of Mr White's family members have had car collisions with kangaroos in recent months on local regional roads.

While both came away uninjured, it reminded the family how risky regional roads can be.

"At 6:45am in the morning when you're heading out of town on your run … you're dodging them everywhere now," he said.

"They are a danger for sure."

Increased collision claims across state

It is not just drivers in the South East who have noticed the increase in kangaroo activity on the roads.

Earlier this year, the RAA released updated statistics which showed a big jump in claims connected to kangaroos across the state.

Survey results of South Australia's kangaroo population are expected to be released by the end of the year. (Supplied: Macro Group Australia)

"We've seen a pretty significant jump in kangaroo collisions this year, probably about 40 per cent higher on what we have been seeing over the past couple of years," RAA senior traffic engineer Matthew Vertudaches said.

"We've seen over the course of this year pretty dry weather conditions, which often do cause wildlife to come closer to the road."

Kangaroo collisions are the most reported collision with wildlife that is reported to the RAA, with over three quarters taking place on regional roads.

"The real concern with this is that we're travelling at high speed," Mr Vertudaches said.

Farmers face growing kangaroo problem in SA Farmers are calling for a cull of kangaroos, which they say are being forced onto farmland by drought and dry conditions and consuming what little feed and water they have.

"Whilst the collision directly with an animal won't usually result in any serious injuries to vehicle occupants, the risk of potentially swerving and colliding with something else on the roadside certainly are there.

"When you do come across wildlife, don't suddenly swerve because a collision with a tree or a Stobie pole or rolling over on the roadside could be a far worse outcome."

Of regional towns Mount Gambier had the highest kangaroo collision claims with RAA in the last year, followed by Whyalla, Port Augusta, Mount Compass, McLaren Vale and Naracoorte.

Roos make up majority of crash repairs

Managing director at Bricey's South East Collision Repairs Leon Brice has been working in the industry for more than four decades.

Leon Brice says a mix of both locals and tourists need repairs from collisions with kangaroos. (ABC South East SA: Elsie Adamo)

About 70 per cent of repair work is due to collisions with kangaroos, but that was not always the case.

"Previously there was a large … variety of collision incidents, we used to do a lot of rollovers, a lot of single-car and two-car impacts," he said.

"But with the introduction of safety features on vehicles … it's definitely made a difference over the years to our work supply for sure.

"Now it's mostly kangaroo collisions we are fixing."

title: $200 a week and tinned fish: Cost of living hits international students
text:
Alipriya Biswas was so short of money when she began studying in Australia, she lived on rice and tinned tuna for a year.

When the 21-year-old journalism student moved from India to Melbourne, she had no friends or family for support — and spent her first night without a bedsheet.

"$200 a week is nothing for an Australian to live on," she said.

"But that's all I had."

Now four years into her studies at the University of Melbourne, Ms Biswas said the experience of international students in Australia was "completely misunderstood".

Alipriya says she had no references to help her smoothly secure a job. (Supplied: Alipriya Biswas )

"Many people think we come here with endless money from rich families and have everything set up when we get off the plane," she said.

"But that's not true."

International students are frequently blamed for adding to rising costs in Australia since the COVID pandemic — despite reports finding they had not been a major driver of higher rents and inflation.

But international students have told the ABC of their own experiences with Australia’s cost-of-living crisis, saying they were struggling to make ends meet.

Researchers studying the pressures on Australia’s international students say many find themselves in highly precarious financial and living situations.

Alipriya says her first job in Australia was a "not quite legal" bartending job in a club. (Unsplash: Naitian Wang)

"There is a lot of suffering out there amongst international students, an enormous amount of stress and anxiety as they try to not only deal with their academic studies, but also try and survive financially," said Alan Morris, a professor focusing on urban and housing studies at the University of Technology, Sydney.

He expects even more international students are experiencing financial hardship since he co-authored a 2020 report finding that one in five were skipping meals because they were short of money.

" For some students, they are very isolated and it's a battle from day one. "

International students come to Australia under visa rules limiting how much they can work while studying, and that require them to have money for living costs before arriving.

They have to prove they have access to $30,000 in order to secure their visas.

Students are only allowed to work 48 hours a fortnight while studying — a rule aiming to let them focus on their learning.

But experts warn the solution to their financial stress is not as simple as changing these visa rules — which they say risks creating other problems for students.

'I was under huge stress'

Ms Biswas's parents made "countless sacrifices" to fund her studies — including cutting back on meals and surviving mostly on lentils and rice back home.

While she proved she had access to $30,000 for living costs and secured her visa, she said the family could only afford to release small amounts after she moved to Melbourne.

The money was not enough, and after six months looking for work, she found a bartending job that helped support her through her studies.

More uncertainty on the cards for international students The past year has seen the international education sector thrown into turmoil, as Labor targeted students in their plan to drive down migration. That uncertainty is set to continue into 2025.

Professor Morris said in many cases, while families of international students paid tuition fees, they expected them to work and pay their own living costs.

About 36 per cent of students relied on paid work for their main income, and for students from low-income countries, that figure was 78 per cent, according to the 2020 report on international students.

"Those students that come from low-income families [are] especially vulnerable because they can't go back to their parents necessarily and ask for more money," Professor Morris said.

Others who could receive more help from their families were reluctant to ask.

International students have not driven rents and inflation substantially higher, RBA says An RBA paper suggests the rapid growth in foreign students post-pandemic did not play a big role in pushing rents higher.

One international student from China studying at the Australian National University, who asked to remain anonymous, said she was surprised at the high cost of food in Australia.

"In China, restaurants are very cheap. We eat out a lot — it's part of our lifestyle," she said.

"Here, it's impossible. I ate instant noodles or fast food until I found work."

She started working up to the maximum 48 hours a fortnight on top of her studies to keep up with costs, rather than ask her family for more help.

The pressures of working while studying felt overwhelming at times.

"Uni is very hard … and I was under huge stress at that time," she said.

"I couldn't really sleep well and … I was very anxious about many things."

Even for international students who work, the income does not always cover living costs, according to Queenie Kwan Yee Siu, an ANU researcher focusing on the Hong Kong diaspora.

Some international students are surprised by the cost of eating out in Australia compared to their home countries. (Unsplash: Angelyn Sanjorjo)

Professor Morris said international students also found paid work impacted their studies.

"Some students find themselves working two to three jobs and of course their academic results suffer dramatically," he said.

"They tend to underplay their academic work because they're so focused on trying to survive."

Phil Honeywood, chief executive of the International Education Association of Australia, warned against letting international students work more hours, saying it could backfire on their academic performance.

Experts say income from work does not always cover living costs for international students. (ABC News: Maani Truu)

"They're here to study first — work is there to supplement living costs," he said.

"Working more hours won't solve the crisis."

But experts also express doubts about requiring students to have access to more savings to pay living costs, to secure their visas.

"The problem is that cuts out a lot of opportunities for some students to get here in the first place … in a sense, it's robbing Peter to pay Paul," said Gaby Ramia, a professor of policy and society at the University of Sydney.

Looking for a 'win-win' on housing

For My Huynh Ngoc Giang, a 21-year-old IT student from Vietnam, the decision to study in Australia was about comfort and opportunity.

But when she settled on moving to Melbourne, she had not factored in its soaring living costs — especially in housing.

My Huynh Ngoc Giang says international students face some barriers in finding housing. (ABC News: Libby Hogan)

"The rental market is so competitive," she said.

"It took me months to find a place. International students don't stand a chance [without] rental history."

At first, she moved into student accommodation, which cost $500 a week for what she described as "a tiny space".

"You can touch both walls with your arms," she said.

" Even military barracks have more space. "

She found a cheaper share house in the suburbs after several months, although that came with new trade-offs, including long commutes and safety concerns such as travelling home late from class.

Professor Morris said Australia's rising housing costs were likely to have left international students even more financially vulnerable since the pandemic.

"Even finding accommodation would be very difficult," he said.

Australia could look to innovations overseas for solutions, including in Canada, where some international students were living with older people, Professor Morris said.

"In exchange for cheaper rents, the student helps the elder person in terms of washing up, taking the dustbins out, maybe watches TV a couple of nights a week with them," he said.

"It's a win-win situation.

"I really do feel that there's capacity for [universities] to think of more innovative solutions rather than just letting international students find their way."

Professor Ramia said access to public transport concessions equal to domestic students, and access to healthcare benefits would also help relieve pressure.

What it’s really like to be an international student in Australia A report reveals international students experience poorer mental health than their domestic counterparts.

Experts also said there was information available to help students research Australia's living costs before deciding to move, while the Australian government also has an online calculator tool.

A spokesperson for Assistant Minister for International Education, Julian Hill, said the federal government was "sympathetic to the financial stress that some international students may face while studying in Australia".

"It is important to remember that international students are required to demonstrate their ability to financially support their studies prior to coming to Australia as part of the student visa application process," they said.

"We want international students to be able to do what they came here to do. Settings around work hours are designed to strike a balance between providing opportunities for international students to work without compromising their education."

Adapting to cost of living pressures

Despite its living costs, researchers say Australia remains attractive for international students compared to other countries.

There were more than 1 million international student enrolments last year.

"We're one of the only countries where students can bring their partners, who can work full-time," Mr Honeywood said.

Australia also offers two to three years of full-time post-study work, helping graduates repay loans and build careers, he said.

Ms Queenie Siu, the ANU researcher, said many students were also using their experiences of the cost-of-living crisis as a chance to pick up new skills helping them cut costs, like cooking or driving.

"That's still very attractive to international students," she said.

My Huynh says finding housing took months of networking and searching. (ABC News: Libby Hogan)

For My Huynh, adapting to her new home means finding ways to make savings where she can.

"Late-night supermarket discounts help too. You just have to be proactive and try things you never thought you would before."

title: The history of the J Awards aligns with Australia's best music
text:
Every November, triple j celebrates Ausmusic Month, commemorating the best and brightest in homegrown music talent.

The centrepiece? The J Awards, a tradition that celebrates its 20th anniversary in 2025.

Similar to station staples like the Hottest 100, Like A Version and One Night Stand, the J Awards is a way for triple j and its sister networks — triple j Unearthed and Double J — to honour the sheer excellence blossoming in our backyard each year.

This year's awards — taking place on Wednesday — is a particularly special milestone, marking two decades of handing out trophies and coinciding with triple j's 50th birthday.

To mark the occasion, we're taking a trip back down Ausmusic memory lane.

Meet all your 2025 J Awards nominees It's time again to crown the annual J Awards winners, celebrating the cream of the crop of Australian music in 2025.

How did the J Awards start?

To commemorate triple j's 30th birthday, the station launched a new annual prize: The J Award.

Initially, it was a single category, Australian Album of the Year, designed — as it does to this day — to celebrate an outstanding record for "its creativity, musicianship, contribution to Australian music, and audience impact."

There were 15 nominees in that first year, reflecting a diverse range of genres, sounds, and scenes from around the nation.

"We knew there'd be one winner but wanted to honour and pay respects to some of the great albums that have come out in the past 12 months," then triple j music director and head of the judging panel, Richard Kingsmill, said at the time.

Contenders included the solo debut from Powderfinger frontman Bernard Fanning, albums from singer-songwriters Ben Lee, Clare Bowditch and Lior, as well as Aussie hip hop acts Downsyde and The Herd.

Heavy rock trio Cog and revered noise rock band The Drones were also in the mix, alongside releases from Architecture In Helsinki, The Beautiful Girls, Faker, Pivot, and WA bands The Panics and Gyroscope.

However, the victor ended up being Sydney-bred rockers Wolfmother with their self-titled debut album, whose woolly, galloping riffs, mystical lyricism and organ-tinged progressive rock harkened back to genre titans like Led Zeppelin and Black Sabbath.

Wolfmother members (from left) Chris Ros, Andrew Stockdale and Myles Heskett accept the inaugural J Award. (triple j)

Led by singer-guitarist Andrew Stockdale, Wolfmother stood apart not only from indie-electro favourites and Modular label-mates The Presets and Cut Copy, but also the rootsy surf rock and homegrown hip hop that was trending around Australia.

"Thanks to triple j for asking for our demo a year-and-a-half ago when we'd played one show at Vic On The Park on a Sunday night," Stockdale told the crowd assembled for the inaugural 2005 J Award ceremony, hosted and broadcast from Sydney's storied Annandale Hotel.

Wolfmother's debut swiftly made them a success at home and abroad, achieving Gold status in the UK, Germany, Canada and the US. In 2006, the band's burly single Woman won the Grammy award for Best Hard Rock Performance, the first Australian Grammy victory in any category since Men At Work in 1984.

The album also won the group three ARIA Awards (Breakthrough Artist, Best Rock Album, Best Group), while six songs charted in triple j's Hottest 100 of 2005 — establishing a record for most songs in a single countdown that lasted almost 20 years.

Where are they now? Wolfmother has struggled to reach the same stratospheric heights since, but Stockdale continues to tour and release albums, including the group's sixth, Rock Out, in late 2021.

The J Awards expand

Hilltop Hoods won the award in 2006 with fourth album The Hard Road, and a second category was added in 2007: the triple j Unearthed Artist of the Year award.

Created to tie in with the online platform and digital radio station, the Unearthed J Award has featured many names who would go on to establish impactful careers.

Among them is Boy & Bear (winners in 2010), Townsville folk collective The Middle East (2009), The Rubens (in 2012, who'd go on to top the Hottest 100), and Meg Mac (2014).

Beloved Brisbane band Ball Park Music, who are currently supporting Oasis on their reunion tour, were named Unearthed Artist of the Year back in 2011.

Their debut album Happiness and Surrounding Suburbs also earned a nod in the album category, giving them the distinction of being the first act in J Awards history with a double nomination.

Ball Park Music accept their Unearthed Artist of the Year award at the 2011 J Awards. (triple j)

First Nations talent like Miss Kaninna, King Stingray and JK-47 win the Unearthed category in recent years, along with Kenyan-Australian artist Elsy Wameyo and Melbourne-based producer and rapper, Lithe.

The very first Unearthed Artist of the Year winner, in 2007, was Young + Restless, beating out nominees Cuthbert and the Nightwalkers, Illzilla, Institut Polaire, and Leroy Lee.

Hailing from Canberra and sporting the angular guitars and club-friendly disco pulse redolent of many late '00s indie acts, Young + Restless won an Unearthed competition to play Homebake festival in 2006 and are best remembered for their singles Police Police and Satan.

Where are they now? Following the release of their debut album in 2007, the band broke up but high school friends, frontwoman Karina Utomo and guitarist Ash Pegram, went on to form hard rock and metal group High Tension in 2012.

Utomo would also front black metal trio Kilat and collaborative project Rinuwat, drawing on her Indonesian heritage and, with the latter, traditional Southeast Asian instrumentation.

Video (did not) kill the radio star

The 2008 J Awards saw club-honed Sydney duo The Presets win Australian Album of the Year with their second album, Apocalypso, while Brisbane six-piece John Steel Singers picked up the Unearthed J Award.

That same year also birthed a new category, Australian Music Video of the Year — a gong that has since been co-presented and evaluated alongside ABC TV's long running late night program, rage.

Loading Instagram content

Notable music video winners over the years include wig-wearing pop sensation Sia with 2014's Chandelier, Client Liaison’s 2017 clip A Foreign Affair featuring Tina Arena, Korean-Australian rap group 1300's 2022 video for Oldboy, and Clubfeet for Everything You Wanted in 2013, which caused a stir when One Direction were accused of copying the clip.

The inaugural 2008 winner, besting videos from The Presets, Angus & Julia Stone, TZU and Josh Pyke, was The Herd's 2020, a critique on Australia's involvement with North America's War On Terror.

Directed by Mike Daly, the clip features members of The Herd — including Elefant Traks co-founder Urthboy — digitally integrated into newspaper print headlines and articles.

Where are they now? Pioneering label Elefant Traks is, sadly, no more, but The Herd are still going strong. In fact, they're heading on tour in February to mark the 20th anniversary of their album The Sun Never Sets.

Director Danny Cohen (third from left), Tash Sultana, D.D Dumbo, and members of King Gizzard & the Lizard Wizard pose with their 2016 J Awards. (triple j)

Significant Accolades

Sarah Blasko became the first female solo artist to taste J Awards glory in 2009, with her third studio album As Day Follows Night, while Washington achieved the same feat the following year in the Australian Music Video category (for Sunday Best, directed by Mairi Cameron and Stephen Lance).

In 2010, the Australian Album of the Year went to InnerSpeaker, the debut from Tame Impala, on which West Australian polymath Kevin Parker lifted from the playbooks of late 1960s and 1970s rock and blues and fused it with psychedelic, homespun textures.

The globally renowned follow-up, 2012's Lonerism, suffused more pop into his kaleidoscopic production. It made Tame Impala the first, and to this day only, artist to have taken out the Australian Album of the Year J Award more than once. Every single one of Tame Impala's subsequent albums has been nominated, including this year's Deadbeat.

A.B. Original, the rap power couple of Briggs and Trials, became the first Indigenous artist to win a J Award, with their 2017 award-hoovering debut Reclaim Australia.

A.B. Original's debut album would win the Australian Music Prize and five trophies at the AIR Awards. (triple j: Zak Kaczmarek)

Gotye scored 2011's marquee J Award with his album Making Mirrors, featuring worldwide hit Somebody That I Used To Know. Meanwhile, super producer Flume's self-titled debut scored the Australian Album of the Year in 2013.

Both instances saw triple j getting ahead of the awards season both locally and internationally, awarding Gotye and Flume before the ARIAs and Grammys did.

Where are they now? After his global success, Gotye, or Wally de Backer to his folks, stepped back from the spotlight to focus on other projects. Namely, launching independent record label Spirit Level with bandmate and former Double J presenter Tim Shiel and embarking on preservation projects for electronic music pioneer Jean-Jacques Perrey and backing the Melbourne Electronic Sound Studio (MESS).

He continues to produce and release music, often with his first band The Basics, but at a much more grassroots scale. Oh, and Kimbra is still somebody that he knows.

A new station, a new award

In 2014, following the launch of Double J, which aimed at an older listening demographic, the Double J Australian Artist of the Year category joined the J Awards festivities.

Established to celebrate an Australian artist of group with a stand-out year through the release of new music, live performances, or making an impact on Australian arts and culture, the inaugural winner was Mia Dyson.

Her more mature songwriting and assured roots-rock sound suited an audience perhaps no longer drawn to the triple j sound, epitomised by Chet Faker and his blue-eyed soultronica on Built On Glass, an album that not only took out the 2014 Australian Album of the Year but dominated the Hottest 100 and ARIA Awards.

Mia Dyson continues to record and tour new music, including her 2024 Double J Feature Album Tender Heart. (triple j)

Other Double J Hall of Famers include rock icons Midnight Oil and Tim Rogers; late, great Indigenous inspirations Archie Roach and Gurrumul; singer-songwriters Jen Cloher and Missy Higgins.

In 2016, the wildly prolific King Gizzard & the Lizard Wizard became the first act to score multiple J Award wins, taking out Double J Australian Artist of the Year and Australian Music Video of the Year (for People-Vultures, directed by Danny Cohen and Jason Galea).

A few years later, dynamic Zambian-Australian rapper Sampa The Great mirrored that milestone, winning the 2019 Double J Australian Artist of the Year and Australian Music Video of the Year (Final Form directed by Sanjay De Silva).

Speaking of double dippers, Claudia Sangiorgi Dalimore is the only director to win the music video J Award twice. First, helming the 2018 clip for Mo'Ju's Native Tongue, and again last year, for Emily Wurramara's Lordy Lordy featuring Tasman Keith.

Loading Instagram content

Done Good and Live Act

In 2019, the J Awards expanded to five categories with the addition of the Done Good Award, designed to recognise achievements outside of traditional music formats.

That included those who might not necessarily be musos themselves, with the initial round of nominees including Paralympian Dylan Alcott, the National Indigenous Music Awards, behind-the-scenes hit-maker Sarah Aarons, and *checks notes* Harry 'the Poo Roadie' for Boy & Bear.

The first Done Good Award went to Heidi Lenffer, recognising her work fronting environmental organisation FEAT.

The category ran for four years, awarding philanthropy work by Kobie Dee, Jaguar Jonze's fearlessness combatting sexual misconduct in the music industry, and COVID-era concert series Isol-Aid.

Heidi Lenffer accepts the 2019 Done Good J Award. (triple j: Jess Gleeson)

In 2023, Done Good was retired for the Australian Live Act of the Year award, celebrating the mind-blowing shows and tours that fans couldn't stop talking about.

Angie McMahon took out the gong last year, while previous J Award victor Genesis Owusu was named the live music winner in its first year.

That made the Ghanian-born, Canberra-based dynamo the artist with the most J Awards to date, following his 2021 sweep of the Australian Album of the Year (for his debut Smiling With No Teeth) and Australian Music Video of the Year (The Other Black Dog directed by Riley Blakeway).

Where are they now? Heidi Lenffercontinues to work with FEAT. on a range of eco-minded campaigns and initiatives to reduce live music’s carbon footprint. She also found time to reunite with the members (including her brother) of Sydney band Cloud Control for a 15th anniversary tour of their J Award-nominated debut album, Bliss Release.

With homegrown music struggling on the ARIA charts, along with Australian festivals and live music venues suffering complex changes, the simple act of recognising the brilliant things happening here at home, honouring and cultivating it, is always welcome.

The 2025 J Awards happens on triple j, Double J, and triple j Unearthed on Wednesday, 12 November. Get all the info here.

title: Oasis leave Australia triumphant after gigantic sold-out tour
text:
"I've waited 20 years for this," the stranger said to me, post hug, about halfway through Oasis's classic Don't Look Back in Anger.

In front of us, another duo — strangers or not — were having the exact same moment, together, arm in arm.

Over to the left, grown men in their 50s, adorned in Oasis Live 25 bucket hats openly wept. For this, after so long and so much disappointment, this was their therapy.

This pure outpouring of emotion was no doubt replicated thousands of times during Oasis's five Australian concerts, in Sydney and Melbourne, over the past week and a half.

Liam Gallagher, on stage in Melbourne, was in fine form for the Australian leg of the world tour. (AAP: Joel Carrett)

Playing to a combined audience of about 320,000 people, Liam and Noel Gallagher's return to Australia for this much-hyped tour has been nothing short of a triumph.

It has taken over social media.

Sparked singalongs on the street.

Loading Instagram content

Given the manufacturers of bucket hats — the unofficial Oasis uniform — an early pathway to retirement.

And even given an economic boost to the two cities — a small bar in Melbourne personally thanked the Gallagher brothers for giving the city's bar scene a much-needed shot in the arm, with fans drinking a week's worth of takings in one day alone.

But, most importantly, this tour, their first in Australia since 2005, has put the spotlight back on Oasis's music: soaring anthems that too often were overshadowed by controversy or petty bickering between the brothers Liam and Noel.

No, not this time.

No way.

I was lucky enough to attend two shows of the Australian tour, one in Melbourne and the band's final show in Sydney on Saturday night.

Coming out hand-in-hand at those two shows (and all five Australian shows), age — and no doubt the promise of as much as $100 million each in takings over the 41-show tour — has seemingly matured the Gallaghers.

This was a celebration; a joyous occasion.

One of the great living rock 'n' roll bands saying: it's good to be back.

There was no sign of past squabbles from Liam and Noel Gallagher in a seamless Australian tour. (AAP: Joel Carrett)

Good to be back

This tour, announced way back in October last year with such fanfare, followed the UK and European tours and, like them, sold out promptly. It was perhaps only rivalled in hype, in recent memory, by Taylor Swift's Era's tour (and yes, she played to more people — about double). But as it has been put to me "this is Eras, Gen X edition".

But still, on the back of the announcement, there were the obvious concerns:

They hate each other, don't they?

Would they actually make it to Australia?

Aren't they just doing it for the money?

From the first chords of Hello, the opener of Oasis's beautifully curated 23-song set, it was obvious: this time things would be different.

Surrounded by gigantic LED screens, the brothers and their brilliant cohort of backing musicians were on song.

They sounded gigantic.

This was a different line-up from last time, when in 2009 the siblings' bitter feud boiled over into a scuffle moments before arriving on stage to play Rock en Seine festival in Paris.

This was a band that appreciated the past and did not feel squeamish about it, embracing it and making it soar.

Fireworks marked the end of the Australian tour in Sydney on Saturday night. (ABC News: Nick Sas)

Leaning heavily on their glory years of the mid-1990s, the boys led the adoring masses in front of them on a singalong of their greatest hits set, leaving no-one disappointed.

Live Forever.

Stand By Me.

Champagne Supernova.

Wonderwall

Don't Look Back in Anger.

They were all there — the last three in an encore that was utterly euphoric.

Watch Take 5 with Zan Rowe on ABC iview Icons in music and screen join Double J host Zan Rowe to delve deep into intimate moments in their lives as they share five songs they love.

"There was a moment where Oasis started to play one of my songs and everyone joined in," Noel Gallagher, nicknamed The Chief, told Zan Rowe in 2023, reminiscing about the writing of the band's first album.

"And at that moment I was like, 'We are going to rule the f***ing world!'"

Looking around at both the Melbourne and Sydney shows, you could not argue otherwise.

Live forever

Of course, the tour was served up with a heavy dose of nostalgia.

But interestingly, amongst the archetypal English lad crowd (yes, there were tens of thousands of them, absolutely loving it) a new generation has discovered these tunes.

"I was up at the Etihad [Stadium] in Manchester last night and a couple of young lads, teenagers — could've only been one or two when we broke up — were like … massive fans and getting giddy," Noel said in the same 2023 interview.

"It's an amazing thing that it's stood the test of time."

They have. And if the hundreds of thousands of Australians Oasis fans — both young and old — are anything to go by, they'll continue to live on through the generations.

As Noel's brother, Liam, said as they left the stage in Sydney on Saturday night: "I know we can be twats, but thanks for sticking with us."

It's good to be back.

title: Stunned Wallabies 'hurting' after shock capitulation to Italy
text:
Wallabies captain Harry Wilson says he is "hurting" after Australia's 26-19 loss to Italy, while coach Joe Schmidt is lamenting his side's "flat performance".

Displaying all-too-familiar ill-discipline, the Wallabies surrendered a second-half lead to slump to a sixth defeat in their past eight Tests under Schmidt in another hammer blow ahead of next month's 2027 Rugby World Cup draw.

Currently ranked seventh in the world, the Wallabies will likely need to beat powerhouses Ireland and France in their remaining two spring tour fixtures to snatch an all-important top-six seeding for the global showpiece in Australia in two years' time.

Italy vs Wallabies live The Wallabies slump to consecutive defeats on their spring tour, as Italy comes from behind to win in Udine.

Such a scenario looks highly unlikely after the Wallabies produced another insipid performance, a week after falling 25-7 to England at Twickenham.

The last time Australia lost to Italy, for a first time ever three years ago in Florence, fellow New Zealand coach Dave Rennie was sacked barely a month later.

Rugby Australia has already locked in Les Kiss to take over from Schmidt in mid-2026.

Narrow wins over Argentina and Japan have been Australia's only two victories in eight Tests since the Wallabies' mighty triumph over the world champion Springboks at Ellis Park in August.

Stream End Game with Tony Armstrong on ABC iview Tony Armstrong tackles Australia's overdue reckoning with racism in sport with the help of some of its biggest sports stars.

Schmidt's winning strike rate has now slumped to 42 per cent, one of the worst Wallabies coaching returns in history.

"I'm pretty gutted, to be honest," Schmidt told Stan Sport.

"We just look a bit flat. I said progress isn't linear, but that was a flat performance. That's a dip we can't afford to have.

"And we've got two massive games coming up now, so we're going to have to just recuperate as best we can and throw everything into the Irish game now."

Skipper Harry Wilson was also unable to hide his anguish after the latest setback.

"We're hurting," he said.

"We wanted to fix up from last week. We said 'we're going to fix it up' and we didn't.

"We want to be a team that does what we said we're going to do and we didn't do that tonight."

The Wallabies face Ireland next Sunday morning (AEDT) in Dublin, before finishing their spring tour against France in Paris.

AAP

title: Spearmint milk and Hawaiian packs: WA's food delicacies in exhibition
text:
"Everyone has a relationship with food," David Craddock, manager of heritage and engagement at the State Library of Western Australia, says.

In A Recipe for Life: The Food That Shapes Us, the library has delved into its archives of photography, films and even old menus and advertisements to tell the story of how we eat, from pre-colonial times to the present day.

"We all need to eat, and we've found food has enabled us to explore all kinds of things — migration, gender, economics, commerce," Mr Craddock says.

The Recipe for Life exhibition celebrates WA's food culture and history. (ABC News: Emma Wynne)

It is all there on the walls of the ground floor, the maps and early photographs, the oral history, the menus of once-fashionable, long-forgotten restaurants that the librarians of the time were savvy enough to add to their collection.

And on one panel, the story of WA's part in an industry that never wins Michelin stars but which figures in many fond childhood memories.

The founders of WA's early takeaway venues were enterprising and looked to America for new ideas.

While fish and chips had long been a staple, the rising affordability of chicken in the 1970s and the entry to Australia of US brand Kentucky Fried Chicken inspired locals to have a go.

The official opening of a new Red Rooster Barbecued Chicken store in Perth, 1973. (Supplied: State Library of Western Australia)

The first Red Rooster outlet in Australia opened in Kelmscott, in Perth's south-eastern fringe.

The founders were Peter and Theo Kailis, a family of Greek migrants famous, then as now, for their involvement in the seafood industry.

"The Kailis family is all throughout this exhibition," Mr Craddock says.

"Their family has made an inordinate contribution to food in Western Australia."

Chicken Treat in 1990. (Supplied: State Library of Western Australia)

While the family's heart may have been in fish, they were quick to spot how popular chicken and chips would prove to be.

"Fast food really did spring up in the 70s. We had things like fish and chip shops and that sort of fast food, but when we're talking about chains and things like that, it was the 70s," food historian Lauren Samuelsson says.

"Australians had always loved films. We would go to the cinema quite a bit, and so a lot of American influence came through that," Dr Samuelsson says.

"We were pretty obsessed with America at that time."

And while they might have been inspired by KFC, there was a local spin on the preparation — the rotisserie chicken.

Lauren Samuelsson says deep-fried pineapple is a very Australian thing. (Supplied: Lauren Samuelsson)

"The rotisserie chicken was definitely an Australian thing," Dr Samuelsson says.

" I can't think of a fast-food restaurant in America that does the rotisserie chicken like Red Rooster does. "

It was also the time when chicken was in transition from being a luxury food in the post-war decades — more expensive than beef or lamb — to becoming a more affordable, everyday food.

"For Australians in the 1970s, chicken had only just become really affordable for people," Dr Samuelsson says.

"People didn't eat out as much, so if you're going to have a takeaway or something, then a roast chicken would seem like a pretty special thing to be eating."

Was this Perth's first fast food joint? When Bernard Hardwick started selling finger food from caravans in 1939, he may have become the first to sell fast food in Perth and quickly became a city institution.

The American influence was added to with the addition of the Hawaiian pack, devised by Peter Kailis to throw a deep-fried banana and pineapple ring into the meal.

Dr Samuelsson believes it fits with the trends at the time.

"The pineapple is a very Australian thing. If you think of an Aussie burger or whatever, the thing that defines that is the pineapple and the beetroot. It's something that we really adopted pretty quickly," she says.

"And then that Hawaiian, tropicana vibe was really popular throughout the 50s and 60s, you think tiki bars and stuff like that were really popular.

" So I can see why he would think that a bit of pineapple and a banana fritter would be the way to go with a piece of chicken. "

While the Kailis brothers sold the Red Rooster business in 1981, Peter Kailis continued to enjoy Hawaiian packs into his 90s and remained proud of his role in the business.

A host of other local chicken takeaways sprang up, many now lost to history or subsumed by Red Rooster, but Chicken Treat, the chain founded by Frank Romano, still remains a WA-only chain, despite sharing an owner with Red Rooster.

Hungry Jack's on William Street in Perth, circa 1977. The menu board shows the price of a Whopper was 85 cents. (Supplied: State Library of Western Australia)

In line with the craze for all things American, after McDonald's entered Australia in 1971, local businessman Jack Cowin looked at US rival Burger King.

But, with another restaurant already named Burger King, Mr Cowin named the local version Hungry Jack's and opened the first outlet in the Perth suburb of Innaloo in 1971.

It has now spread across Australia and is still owned by Jack Cowin's private company.

While fast-food outlets are generally prized for the uniformity and consistency of their offering, leaving little room for state differences, there are some West Australian treats that stand out.

A Masters Milk truck in 1954. (Supplied: State Library of Western Australia)

While many dairies experimented with flavoured milk, Masters Dairy, which was established just outside Perth in Byford in 1925, put its own twist on the product.

As well as coming out with chocolate and strawberry, they also came out with a green-coloured, spearmint-flavoured milk.

"We do tend to have our own little unique bubbles," Mr Craddock says.

" Spearmint milk, I think, is a very WA thing. "

Spearmint milk was developed in 1964 and seems to have remained a West Australian delicacy. (ABC News: Emma Wynne)

Evidence for its existence in other states is patchy.

"I have never heard of it, and I grew up in Queensland," Dr Samuelsson says.

"I can give you anecdotal evidence that it wasn't around in Queensland in the 80s and 90s."

But she's keen to try it.

"I really like chocolate mint ice cream. I'm imagining a similar sort of vibe."

A Recipe for Life: The Food That Shapes Us is at the State Library of Western Australia's ground floor gallery until March 22, 2026, and entry is free.

title: Women's pain inquiry finds health system based on 'Caucasian male biology'
text:
The first inquiry of its kind into women's pain in Australia has found widespread experiences of dismissal, disrespect and inadequate treatment in the health system coupled with limited local and international research into women's health.

The inquiry was conducted by the Victorian government's Women's Health Advisory Council and a panel of experts between January and October 2024.

It examined barriers to accessing care, the effectiveness of current services and the reforms needed to improve pain management and healthcare outcomes.

There were more than 13,000 responses from Victorian women and girls, clinicians, researchers and peak bodies.

"The results can make for difficult reading," Health Minister Mary-Anne Thomas said on Sunday while releasing the inquiry's report.

"The most common conditions that women are experiencing include period, pain, endometriosis and arthritis.

"The report goes on to tell us that the impacts of these are not just the physical pain itself, but this leads to poor mental health, fatigue, poor sleep and low self-esteem."

The report found a health system built around the biology of white males left many women without effective diagnosis and treatment. (Supplied: Endometriosis Australia)

The report found 90 per cent of respondents experienced pain that lasted over a year, with half saying they were experiencing it daily and a third saying they were in pain constantly.

Women with disabilities and from the LGBTIQA+ community reported higher rates of prolonged pain.

The report found the healthcare system was built around "Caucasian male biology", making it difficult for women and girls to access care and support for pain.

It said historically low investment in women's health research left many without effective pain relief or treatment, causing their symptoms to worsen and forcing them to spend substantial amounts of money on therapies, some of which may not work.

"Many medical models and clinical guidelines overlook sex and gender differences, leading to gaps in diagnosing and treating conditions that affect women, girls and gender diverse people," the report said.

Ninety per cent of respondents told the inquiry they had experienced pain that lasted more than a year. (Unsplash: Anthony Tran)

More than half of the respondents said their pain affected their recreation and hobbies as well as their intimate relationships, while 44 per cent said it had an impact on their work, studies, or volunteering.

An overwhelming majority of women with disabilities — 89 per cent — said their pain also affected their mental wellbeing, sleep, caused feelings of shame, guilt and helplessness, and thoughts of self-harm for some.

Women living in regional and rural Victoria often had to travel long distances to access health care, while Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women experienced systemic discrimination.

"Women want to be heard without bias or judgement, treated with empathy and respect, empowered to make informed decisions about their health, and able to access affordable, effective care easily," the report authors wrote.

" Women, girls and gender diverse people with living and lived experiences of pain deserve to live fulfilling lives and participate fully in the economy and society. "

Thea Baker made a submission to the inquiry after receiving multiple surgeries for endometriosis and adenomyosis, as well as a hip replacement for arthritis over the past 10 years.

She now works as a psychotherapist treating women with complex trauma.

"I'm really hoping that this inquiry and the results and the initiatives that are announced today are the beginning of really widespread systemic change within our medical system … so that women are believed, they are validated, their experiences are understood but primarily that they get efficient access to effective and evidence-based and above all compassionate care," she said.

"Women make up 51 per cent of the population so I don't really understand why we're considered a special population."

Thea Baker says she hopes the report into women's page leads to systemic change. (ABC News)

The report has made 27 recommendations in seven key areas, including:

more focus and funding for women's health research

the development of a women's pain action plan

improved education and training for health providers

a culture change to reduce gender bias and stigma

clearer referral pathways and cross-sector information sharing

attracting and retaining clinicians to regional and rural areas

advocating for the federal government to help make health care more affordable and accessible, including an increased investment in women's pain services.

"Women and girls told the Victorian government how to put an end to their unnecessary suffering and eradicate the barriers they face when seeking help," the report concluded.

"Your voices are now being heard.

"We hope that, in time, we can improve pain care and the overall health and wellbeing of all Victorian women and girls."

Delayed report release accompanied by IUD pain relief announcement

The inquiry's final report has been delayed by more than half a year.

Victorian inquiry into women's pain quietly delayed Women who have spent years navigating the health system seeking care for extreme pain say they are frustrated at the slow pace of a government inquiry into the issue.

It was due to be made public early this year, then an updated release date was given as "mid-2025".

It has finally been released on Sunday.

Ms Thomas attributed the delay to the "overwhelming" number of submissions it received.

She said she did not expect "the breadth of the challenge" faced by Victoria.

"This is not just a challenge for the Victorian health system," she said.

" This is a challenge across the nation and, indeed, around the world. "

She said Victoria would develop a new clinical pain standard to help women receive more effective treatment.

"We need to work with our healthcare workforce, with our universities, with the medical colleges to address this issue.

"It's a big system issue, so it's going to take some time to change."

Mary-Anne Thomas says the report was difficult to read. (ABC News)

She also announced the establishment of a specialist clinic at the Royal Children's Hospital.

The hospital's head of gynaecology, Sonia Glover, said some girls were missing school every month because of period pain, yet their experiences were being overlooked.

"That changes today," Professor Glover said.

She said early intervention could have lifelong benefits.

"A beautiful study done out of Oxford [university] recently published showed that teenagers who had horrible period pain have got a 75 per cent chance of having chronic pain of any sort 10 years later," she said.

"I hope that we can have fewer adult women with chronic pain problems, fewer problems with infertility."

Joining Ms Thomas in releasing the report was the premier Jacinta Allan, who announced Penthrox — commonly known as the green whistle — would be offered at 20 sexual and reproductive health hubs in Victoria to women receiving IUDs.

Frankston Hospital, in Melbourne's south, began trialling the use of the pain relief for the procedure in 2023.

"What the green whistle does is give women control over managing their pain but also over their body and their reproductive choices," Ms Allan said.

Jacinta Allan announces the green whistle will be used for pain relief during IUD procedures at 20 reproductive health clinics. (ABC News)

She also revealed the difficulties she had experienced when she was younger as she tried to find help to diagnose and treat her endometriosis and subsequent fertility issues.

"Whether it's the heavy periods, the crippling cramps … we're taught we just have to push through it and put up with it," she said.

Why can getting an IUD be so painful? IUDs are one of the most effective forms of contraception, but for some women getting one inserted can be excruciating. Here's why.

"For too many women and girls, they're not being listened to, which means in turn they're not getting the treatment they need and deserve."

Nisha Kot, an obstetrician and senior leader at the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, welcomed the rollout of the green whistle.

"We all know that an IUD is an excellent contraceptive, it's also good for heavy periods," Dr Kot said.

"It seemed like such a shame that women were not able to use an IUD because their experience of getting an IUD inserted or changed was so painful."

title: Uncertainty for small-scale Tasmanian farmers over new food safety rules
text:
At Sparrow Foot Farm in Tasmania's Huon Valley, selling produce directly to customers has been relatively straightforward for co-owners Ines Santos and David Simmons.

The pair's 3-hectare market garden supplies a vegetable box program along with stalls at farmers' markets.

But proposed food safety standards for leafy greens, berries and melons have them and other small- and medium-scale producers uncertain about the viability of their businesses.

Biosecurity Tasmania is consulting on the new regulations, which were developed by Food Standards Australia and New Zealand following increased foodborne illness outbreaks in Australia linked to horticultural products.

The new regulations would apply to leafy vegetables, berries and melons. (ABC News: Madeleine Rojahn)

Biosecurity Tasmania said the regulations would help protect the state's industry and reputation.

"Between 2011 and 2019 there were a number of outbreaks [of] salmonella," Biosecurity Tasmania's product integrity manager Jim Beck told ABC Mornings last week.

"There were also 10 deaths and 275 reported cases."

Mr Beck said other viruses, including hepatitis A had also been found in horticultural products.

The changes would bring the state into line with national standards.

The regulations would bring Tasmania into line with other states. (ABC News: Madeleine Rojahn)

Calls for a 'tiered' approach

In the draft released for public consultation, the regulations outline an "annual accreditation fee" that is set according to a farm's number of full-time employees. The cost ranges from $175 to $750.

But a tiered approach is not stated for other accreditation fees and auditing requirements that are set out in the regulations.

It has smaller growers worried they will have to meet commercial standards.

Mr Simmons said farms such as Sparrow Foot did not pose the same risk as large operations where products were handled more from seed to sale.

"In terms of vegetables going across the country, some of the regulations there make sense," Mr Simmons said.

" But in terms of local growers and farms selling direct to their customers, I don't think it makes a lot of sense. "

David Simmons says some of the regulations do not make sense for producers who sell directly to customers. (ABC News: Madeleine Rojahn)

Biosecurity Tasmania has said it was "looking at a tiered approach" to make the new regulations "practical and achievable" for small and medium-sized growers.
